issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies getTotalNumberOfStudents() should return an int, but the solution implementation declares getTotalNumberOfStudents() to return a StudentCount object (and adds a StudentCount class). This is a method return type mismatch between the specification and the provided solution. Students following the problem statement/UML (and implementing the method in the template) will naturally implement/expect an int, while the solution uses a custom type, causing confusion and preventing straightforward comparison between student implementations and the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix:
Align the solution with the problem specification and UML. Either:

1) Preferred: Change the solution so getTotalNumberOfStudents() returns an int (the sum of inscribed and guest students). Update getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents() and getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor() to use the int return value, and remove the StudentCount class from the solution repository. This preserves the UML and the intuitive API students will implement from the template/problem statement.

2) Or: If the intent was to introduce a StudentCount type, update the problem statement and UML to specify getTotalNumberOfStudents(): StudentCount and mention the StudentCount class in the instructions, and add a StudentCount placeholder to the template so students see and can use the type. (Less recommended unless the exercise intends to teach custom return types.)

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) specifies getTotalNumberOfStudents() as returning an int (primitive total number). In the solution implementation, getTotalNumberOfStudents() returns an instance of a StudentCount class instead of an int. This introduces a new identifier (StudentCount) for the same conceptual entity (the total number of students) and changes the method's API compared to the exercise description. Students expecting an int return type (per the problem and UML) can be confused by the wrapper class, and automated tests or starter code that assume an int may not map cleanly to the solution's API.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem statement by making getTotalNumberOfStudents() return a primitive int (the sum of inscribed and guest students). For example, change the signature in Lecture to public int getTotalNumberOfStudents() { return numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents; } and update any callers (e.g., getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents and getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor) to use the int. Alternatively, if a wrapper type is pedagogically intended, update the problem statement/UML to mention StudentCount and specify the method should return StudentCount so all artifacts use the same identifier.
